awd_titl_txt: RAPID: Immediate Behavioral Response to Flash-Floods in Uttarakhand, North India
awd_abstract_narration:
The objective of this Rapid Response Research (RAPID) proposal is to better understand people's immediate response to the June 16th - 17th, 2013 flash floods in the hilly state of Uttarakhand in North India. This event has claimed over 1,000 lives with over 5,700 still reported missing and presumed dead as of early August. Data will be collected through field observations and semi-structured interviews of over 300 flash flood survivors from six affected villages. The interviews with survivors will examine their traditional knowledge about floods and landslides and actions they take, their understanding of how the environment changes, number of floods they have experienced, their sources of warning, the actions they took prior to evacuating, their emotional state at the time of the flash floods, and their responses related to protecting themselves, their family and friends. The project activities will advance the state of knowledge about people's response to flash floods and provide a foundation for cross-cultural comparisons of flash flood response. This will be extremely significant because there are few studies of flood response and virtually none on flash flood response in developing countries. Adopting questionnaire items from previous surveys used will provide a basis for comparing responses to the Uttarakhand flash floods with responses to other rapid-onset hazards (the Mt. St. Helens mudflows, the Christchurch and Hitachi earthquakes, and the American Samoa earthquake and tsunami). 

University contacts made in India during the data collection stage will be of value in catalyzing future collaborations for faculty and student exchanges and research endeavors between UNT and Delhi University. The project activities will advance teaching, training, and learning in the US as the project findings will be incorporated into course modules by the PI. Lectures and exercises will be developed in undergraduate and graduate classes such as Special Populations, Sustainability and Emergency Management, Foundations of Emergency Management, Disaster Response Planning and Disaster Research Methods, reflecting the findings and challenges of disaster management in a developing country. This study will also provide field research and data collection experience to five Indian graduate students and data coding, analysis, and publication experience to a doctoral student at UNT.

por.por_cntn:
Background: Flash floods are some of the most dangerous weather-related disasters, as they are involuntary risks where individuals are unaware of the onset of the event and have no control over how the event will affect them. Consequently, people’s immediate response is very likely to determine whether they survive the event. Unfortunately, there is nonexistent literature on this topic in developing countries of the world where official flash flood warning systems are lacking. The major goal of this research funded by the US National Science Foundation is to fill this gap and inform policy by understanding people’s immediate response to the June 17th 2013 flash floods in the Himalayan state of Uttarakhand in North India. The flash flood and resultant landslides resulted in 1,000 confirmed deaths and over 5,700 missing individuals, later presumed dead.

Theoretical framework: This research was guided by the Protective Action Decision Model (Lindell and Perry 1992, 2004, 2012), which identifies three core drivers that cause an emotional reaction in humans and influence their decisions on how to respond or take protective actions to an imminent threat-----1) the severity of the threat and the perceived destruction from it; 2) the ability or inability to take actions to protect oneself and one’s family and; 3) knowledge, responsibility and trustworthiness of stakeholders in the community including the local, state, and federal government, media and peers, to protect them from the threat. It is posited that the outcome of the protective action decision-making process, together with situational facilitators and impediments, produces a behavioral response that can help save lives and reduce losses.

Sample selection: Flood survivors were identified and interviewed face-to-face in the local language (Hindi) between October 16 and November 1, 2013 by a five-member research team of students (Delhi University), led by the PI, four months after the disaster.  A convenience snowball sampling strategy was adopted to identify respondents.  Interviews were conducted in respondents’ homes, in the central market by the side of the highway, or at government or nonprofit-sponsored tent shelters. In all, 316 respondents from 17 villages were surveyed. Secondary information was also collected from government and media reports.

Findings and Discussions: Respondents’ ages ranged from 18 to 85, with a mean of 43 years. Approximately 59% were male and 75% married, 35% single, divorced, or widowed. Respondent households included an average of six members, with approximately two children under the age of 18. The modal education level was less than 9th grade. Seeing the flash flood coming (37.3%), understanding that torrential rains would cause flash flooding (23.1%), and observing unusual changes in the mountains (5.4%) were people’s primary environmental cues. Contrary to findings in developed countries, results show that most respondents received their first information from social sources such as friends, family and other villagers (46%) or observed it themselves (42%), rather than from the mass media and only 7% from the police, who serve as disaster management authorities in these communities. This clearly demonstrates a dependence on social and familial networks for hazard warnings in these remote rural communities and possibly a lack of funding for disaster mitigation and management

Most respondents reported their homes were either moderately damaged (14.6%), severely damaged (25.0%), or completely destroyed (48.4%), but only 9.2% had a family member killed or injured. Furthermore, findings clearly demonstrate that although over 98% villagers had never experienced a flash flood in the past 10 years, their social perceptions motivated them to take adequate protective actions that saved the lives of their families and themselves. Despite a lack of a well-established flash flood warning system or educational campaigns and assistance from the government and the mass-media, these villagers’ traditional knowledge about their environment and social connections helped them survive.

There is a need for multi-sector agencies including the media to warn the populace by providing up to date accurate data on unusual rainfall levels that could potentially cause flash floods and landslides. It also highlights the importance of involving the villagers in risk communication and warning messaging that integrates their traditional knowledge and capacities in order to empower them and reduce losses to lives and property to future threats.

Broader impacts: This research advances the state of knowledge about people’s response to flash floods, in particular, and provides a foundation for cross-cultural comparisons of flash flood response, more generally. Both of these achievements are extremely significant because there are few studies on flood response and virtually none on flash flood response within developing countries. Adopting questionnaire items from previous surveys provides a basis for comparing responses to the Uttarakhand flash floods with responses to other rapid-onset hazards like mudflows, earthquakes, and tsunamis. The study also provided data coding, analysis, and writing experience for one doctoral student in the USA and data collection experience to five graduate students in India.
